Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of "The Little Prince" animated adaptations, TV specials, international versions, and their cultural impact on children:

## Major Animated Adaptations

### 1. The Adventures of the Little Prince (1978)
This Japanese anime series, originally titled "Hoshi no Ōjisama Puchi Puransu" (Prince of the Stars: Petit Prince), was created by Knack animation studio and first aired in Japan in 1978. The English-language version aired in the United States on ABC and later Nickelodeon during the 1980s. The English version altered the premise, having the Little Prince travel to Earth and planets that resembled it, helping people at various places and returning home at the end of each episode.

### 2. The Little Prince (2010-2017 TV Series)
This French animated television series consisting of 52 episodes of 26 minutes each was created by Method Animation. The series was part of updated adaptations created through an agreement with the Saint-Exupéry–d'Agay Estate, designed to make The Prince more attuned to children of the 21st century. Pierre Alain Chartier directed the show with a crew of 450 people.

### 3. The Little Prince (2015 Film)
This animated film was directed by Mark Osborne, the director of the original "Kung Fu Panda" movie. The film combined stop-motion animation for the book adaptation parts with regular 3D animation for the new story elements. The film proved commercially successful, earning $97 million worldwide, including $24 million from China.

## International Reach and Cultural Impact

### Global Distribution
The original novella has been translated into more than 250 languages and dialects, selling close to two million copies per year with total sales exceeding 140 million copies worldwide. The 2010 TV series was produced in collaboration with France Télévisions, TV5 Monde, Swiss Télévision Suisse Romande, and Italian Rai Fiction, and was licensed for distribution in many countries worldwide.

### Cultural Impact on Children
The 2015 film addresses essential themes for the present world, showing how children are enforced by their parents into mechanical lives with less time to play and make friends, lacking the creativity to create fictional worlds with their toys like children from a century ago. The film explores the message that "Growing up is not the problem. Forgetting is," highlighting how children are losing their innocence to the adult's reality world.

### Educational Value
The film serves as an encouraging message for parents about how not to raise their children and for grown-ups about how not to get lost in the adult world. The TV series is described as offering "trips and adventures, planet and temptations, delicate story about basic values" as an admirable adaptation of the classic book.

## Recent and Future Developments

### New Spin-off Series (2023)
In 2021, Method Animation announced "The Little Prince & Friends," a spin-off featuring the titular character joining two children named Charlotte and Elijah to solve everyday problems on various planets. The series premiered in Italy on Rai Yoyo in August 2023 and in France on France 5 in September 2023.

### Upcoming Chinese Adaptation
A new animated adaptation is in development by Stars Collective and El Pajaro Pictures Shanghai, focusing on Saint-Exupéry's life between 1940 and 1944, using hybrid animation techniques blending 2D watercolor styles for The Little Prince's world with 3D oil painting aesthetics for the author's real-life experiences.

The enduring appeal of "The Little Prince" across multiple animated adaptations demonstrates its universal themes resonate with children worldwide, teaching valuable lessons about imagination, friendship, and the importance of maintaining childlike wonder in an increasingly mechanized world.
